H0.text: Both plant and animal cells have a cell wall to give them support.

H1.text: Both plant and animal cells have a large vacuole to store water.

H2.text: Both plant and animal cells use mitochondria to produce energy.

H3.text: Both plant and animal cells use chloroplasts to store energy.

A4.text: Mitochondrial ATP production is also vital for cell division and differentiation in infection in addition to basic functions in the cell including the regulation of cell volume, solute concentration, and cellular architecture.

A5.text: Some cells in some multicellular organisms lack mitochondria (for example, mature mammalian red blood cells).

A6.text: The vacuoles of plant cells are usually larger than those of animal cells.

A7.text: Eukaryotic cells contain other membrane-bound organelles such as mitochondria, which provide energy for cell functions.
